Events.RelatedDescription: Opened pull request "Remove in-memory caching from endpoints that are cached by APIM" (#9139) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Resolve https://github.com/NuGet/Engineering/issues/4370

These values are currently dialed down to 0 on all environments anyway.

Events.RelatedDescription: Merged pull request "[ReleasePrep][2022.06.06]RI of dev into main" (#9136) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Merged pull request "Remove the trailing slash when formatting the tab fragment" (#9138) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
The search result may point to a URL like this:
https://dev.nugettest.org/packages/Newtonsoft.Json/

The existing approach appends the tab fragment like this:
https://dev.nugettest.org/packages/Newtonsoft.Json/#versions-body-tab

This is to remove the trailing slash when formatting the tab fragment:
https://dev.nugettest.org/packages/Newtonsoft.Json#versions-body-tab

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Nuget package update reformats config files poorly or creates unwanted config files" (#7180) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
The [VS Feedback item](https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/content/problem/182303/nuget-package-update-reformats-config-files-poorly.html) has the original unredacted attachment illustrating the problem.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/15381181/43792564-1316de9a-9a47-11e8-8a2f-087223997ff4.png)
In this redacted example, you can see its removed the line breaks as well as changed the spacing before the closing element. Its changing the formatting of config files in this manner for projects that are not having any binding redirects added or changed, and for projects that aren't being targeted for the package update.  

Its also creating new app.config files for projects that didnt have them and don't need them (class libraries).

All of these are a tedious venture to cleanup before checkin or submitting for code review. On larger solutions (> 50 projects) this can easily take an hour or more to clean up - every time a single package is updated in a project in the solution.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Feature]: nuget.exe uninstall command" (#11850) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product(s) Involved

NuGet.exe

### The Elevator Pitch

nuget.exe has an install command but no uninstall command.  This is an obvious oversight and quite annoying when needed.
This is especially important when nuget.exe has been run outside any project, thus making the installed packages unavailable to commands that can only be run in a project context.

### Additional Context and Details

Running "nuget.exe install packagename" outside any project installs the package under the current directory where the user happens to run the command.  Such packages don't appear in the output of PowerShell Get-Package, and there is no easily found information on how to list or remove packages installed that way.

If this installation method is unintended and removed in a future nuget.exe version, users will still need a tool to uninstall those things.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Bug]:  dotnet.exe errors when using any cache folder." (#11863) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

dotnet.exe

### Product Version

Version: 5.0.17   Commit:  6a98414363

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

It bothers me. A fix would be nice

### Repro Steps & Context

Build a windows app using the Drone CI.
I checked the environment. The pipeline does not have `LOCALAPPDATA`.

#### Reproduce step:
- Remove `LOCALAPPDATA` environment at powershell
- Run `dotnet nuget locals all -l`

### Verbose Logs

```shell
---> System.ArgumentNullException: Value cannot be null. (Parameter 'path1')
                        at System.IO.Path.Combine(String path1, String path2, String path3)
                        at NuGet.Common.NuGetEnvironment.GetFolderPath(NuGetFolderPath folder)
                        at NuGet.Configuration.SettingsUtility.GetHttpCacheFolder()
                        at NuGet.Protocol.HttpSource.GetAsync[T](HttpSourceCachedRequest request, Func`2 processAsync, ILogger log, CancellationToken token)
                        at NuGet.Protocol.ServiceIndexResourceV3Provider.GetServiceIndexResourceV3(SourceRepository source, DateTime utcNow, ILogger log, CancellationToken token)
```

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "[Bug]: nuget.exe doesn't support signatures compressed with deflate method" (#11861) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
### NuGet Product Used

NuGet.exe

### Product Version

6.2.0

### Worked before?

_No response_

### Impact

_No response_

### Repro Steps & Context

We have a local NuGet feed (ProGet) to both store our private packages and move public libraries from nuget.org to our feed.

Somehow, we are getting packages in our internal feed with signature files compressed using the "deflate" method. When we copy .nupkg files from nuget.org to our feed, they are valid. However, for some reason, after some time we are starting to get errors like the following when we are restoring packages from our feed:
```
C:\Nuget\nuget.exe verify -All .\Microsoft.AspNetCore.Http.Features.2.1.1.nupkg

Verifying Microsoft.AspNetCore.Http.Features.2.1.1
...\Microsoft.AspNetCore.Http.Features.2.1.1.nupkg

Finished with 1 errors and 0 warnings.
NU3005: The package signature file entry is invalid. The central directory header field 'compression method' has an invalid value (8).
```

It turns out that in a valid .nupkg file, the signature file is not compressed. And in an invalid package, the signature file is compressed using Deflate method.
![valid-invalid](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/7262311/172415815-338320bc-5116-4e38-9c67-eaa5ae22b53f.png)

Both signatures, if extracted (unzipped) from the package, are binary equal (you can also see the same CRC on the screenshot). So the problem is that for some reason NuGet does not support signatures compressed with deflate method.

We don't realize yet how it is possible that our package feed "repackages" packages and compresses their signatures, but it seems that nuget.exe should support such signatures since they have a perfectly valid compression method in terms of ZIP file format.

Example of a "broken" package:
[Microsoft.AspNetCore.Http.Features.2.1.1.nupkg.zip](https://github.com/NuGet/Home/files/8854398/Microsoft.AspNetCore.Http.Features.2.1.1.nupkg.zip)

### Verbose Logs

_No response_
